value.overview: Modular Express.js architecture with TypeScript, Zod validation, and middleware-based security

routing.structure: Each feature has its own router file in routes/
routing.mounting: Routes mounted on app instance with version prefix /api/v1

validation.implementation: Schemas defined per endpoint, validated via sanitizeInputs middleware
validation.benefits: Type-safe, declarative validation with automatic error handling

ai_integration.approach: Mock data for demo, easily swappable with real AI calls

design_decisions: TypeScript for type safety across the stack
Zod for runtime validation matching TypeScript types
DOMPurify for XSS protection in sanitization
Comprehensive input sanitization with injection protection
Feature flags for demo mode and email notifications
Mock data approach allows testing without external dependencies
Health checks and metrics endpoints for monitoring
strengths: Strong security posture with multiple defense layers
Type safety from validation to business logic
Easy to extend with new features
considerations: Demo routes not yet mounted in server.ts
Authentication routes exist but implementation not shown
Real AI integration will need API key management

Key TypeScript learnings from travel agent project:
1. ALWAYS check for undefined/null before accessing properties (use optional chaining ?. or guards)
2. When defining object types with varying structures, use union types or ensure all properties exist
3. Array access requires bounds checking - use array.length > index before array[index]
4. Type narrowing with 'in' operator for conditional properties (e.g., 'bookingCurve' in patterns)
5. Explicit type assertions needed when TypeScript cannot infer types (use 'as' carefully)
6. Consistent object structures prevent type errors - all MOCK_PRICE_PATTERNS entries should have same shape
7. Use strict null checks to catch potential runtime errors at compile time
8. Define explicit return types for functions to catch type mismatches early

Demo API implementation completed successfully with 4 endpoints, comprehensive tests, and AI prompt integration. All TypeScript errors resolved using swarm coordination and stored best practices. Ready for production deployment.

User data layer implementation complete. Includes: UserDataManager with atomic file operations, proper locking (proper-lockfile), comprehensive validation utilities, full test coverage (25 passing tests), and schemas based on memory-bank/data-schemas.md specifications. Ready for authentication system integration.

value.status: Creating comprehensive tests for password reset and session management

entries.value: Converting AuthService from class-based to functional module. Key steps: 1) Create auth/types.ts with branded types (UserId, SessionId, HashedPassword), 2) Create auth/storage.ts for password operations, 3) Create auth/operations.ts with pure functions for register/login/logout, 4) Create auth/index.ts as public API, 5) Maintain backward compatibility during transition. Result pattern implementation comes in Phase 3.

Current AuthService uses class-based OOP with singleton pattern. Key methods: registerUser, loginUser, logoutUser, validateJWTToken, validateSession. Dependencies: UserDataManager (class), bcrypt, jwt, crypto. Private storage: passwordStorage Map, sessions Map, failedLoginAttempts Map. Tests currently mock private methods storeUserPassword and getUserPasswordHash.

Phase 1 implementation complete: Created functional auth module structure with types.ts (branded types: UserId, SessionId, HashedPassword, Email), storage module (password operations), operations.ts (pure functions for register/login/logout), and index.ts (public API). All core modules are implemented and ready for integration. Next step: ensure backward compatibility with existing AuthService class.

SPARC coder successfully created functional auth module structure with: 1) Branded types (UserId, SessionId, etc.) in types/, 2) Storage abstraction in storage/, 3) Pure functions in operations.ts, 4) Public API in index.ts. Files created: types/index.ts, types/core.ts, types/auth.ts, types/errors.ts, types/result.ts, operations.ts, storage/index.ts, storage/interfaces.ts, session/index.ts, index.ts. Next: Create tests and ensure backward compatibility.

"Phase 2: UserDataManager Functional Refactor Plan

1. Create type definitions:
   - UserDataManagerOps interface with all operations
   - FileOps interface for file operations
   - LockOps interface for locking operations

2. Separate concerns into modules:
   - storage/fileOperations.ts - Low-level file operations
   - storage/lockOperations.ts - Locking abstractions
   - storage/userDataOperations.ts - Business logic functions
   - storage/types.ts - Type definitions and branded types
   - storage/index.ts - Public API factory

3. Create pure functions for each operation:
   - createUser: takes FileOps and returns function
   - readUserData: takes FileOps and returns function
   - updateUserData: takes FileOps and LockOps and returns function
   - deleteUser: takes FileOps and returns function
   - findUserByEmail: takes FileOps and returns function
   - updateUserFlightSearch: takes FileOps and LockOps and returns function
   - getUserFlightSearches: takes FileOps and returns function
   - getStorageStats: takes FileOps and returns function
   - listUsers: takes FileOps and returns function
   - userExists: takes FileOps and returns function

4. Create factory function:
   - getUserDataManagerOps() returns UserDataManagerOps interface
   - Internally creates FileOps and LockOps instances
   - Composes all operations with dependencies

5. Backward compatibility:
   - Keep existing userDataManager export
   - Wrap functional interface with class adapter"

Phase 2 Complete: UserDataManager successfully refactored to functional module. Created 4 new files: types.ts, fileOperations.ts, lockOperations.ts, userDataOperations.ts, index.ts, and userDataManagerCompat.ts for backward compatibility. All 25 tests passing. Ready for Phase 3 (Result pattern implementation).

All 3 phases of functional refactoring complete:
1. Phase 1 ‚úÖ: AuthService converted to functional module with branded types, storage abstractions, and pure functions. Backward compatibility maintained.
2. Phase 2 ‚úÖ: UserDataManager converted to functional module with FileOps, LockOps, and pure operations. All 25 tests passing.
3. Phase 3 ‚úÖ: Result pattern implemented with comprehensive utilities (map, flatMap, all, etc). Auth routes updated to use Result pattern. 28 tests passing.

Next: Build actual authentication system with JWT/sessions using the new functional modules.

Authentication System Complete:
- JWT utility functions with full token lifecycle management
- Session manager with in-memory storage (ready for Redis)
- Functional auth service using Result pattern
- Complete auth endpoints: register, login, logout, refresh, password reset
- Auth middleware for protecting routes
- Integration with UserDataManager for user persistence
- Switch between old/new implementation with USE_NEW_AUTH env var

Next steps: 
1. Add Redis for production session storage
2. Implement email verification flow
3. Add OAuth providers
4. Complete test coverage
5. Migrate from old auth system

MVP Travel Agent plan completed with 5 comprehensive documents: MVP Development Plan, CTO Review (recommending simplified scope), Design Brief, Automated Testing Plan, and Development Guidelines. Key decisions: 3 saved searches max, email-only notifications, TDD mandatory, 7-week timeline.

TEST-DRIVEN DEVELOPMENT IS NON-NEGOTIABLE. All code must follow strict TDD principles from citypaul/.dotfiles. TypeScript strict mode required, no any types, functional programming patterns, immutable data, behavior-driven testing. See /docs/DEVELOPMENT-GUIDELINES.md

MVP has 4 core components: 1) Conversation Engine (Claude API + Redis sessions), 2) Flight Search Service (Amadeus API integration), 3) Saved Search Manager (PostgreSQL, max 3 searches, weekly batch), 4) Notification Service (SendGrid email only). Using functional Result types for error handling.

Friendly professional travel agent. Traits: Professional (uses industry terms), Friendly (warm greetings), Patient (step-by-step guidance), Knowledgeable (provides context), Proactive (suggests alternatives). Voice: Clear, Confident, Helpful, Human. Always provides fallback forms for reliability.

Branch: feature/agent-testing-ui. Frontend-backend chat integration completed and working. Comprehensive MVP planning documents created. Ready for Phase 0 implementation: authentication, monitoring, security baseline. 7-week timeline starting with infrastructure setup.

Phase 0 (Week 1): Auth, monitoring, deployment. Phase 1 (Week 2): Core chat interface. Phase 2 (Week 3): Amadeus integration. Phase 3 (Week 4): Search persistence (3 max). Phase 4 (Week 5): Batch processing. Phase 5 (Week 6): Polish & testing. Phase 6 (Week 7): UAT & launch prep.

{"research_timestamp":"2025-06-28","swarm_coordination_theory":{"communication_overhead":"n(n-1)/2 channels","brooks_law":"Coordination overhead can exceed productivity gains","amdahls_law":"Speedup limited by sequential portions","optimal_team_research":"5-9 people (Two Pizza Rule)"},"optimal_agent_counts":{"simple_crud":{"min":2,"max":3,"optimal":2,"rationale":"Minimal coordination needed for modular tasks"},"complex_system_design":{"min":5,"max":7,"optimal":5,"rationale":"Balance expertise needs with communication overhead"},"testing_qa":{"min":4,"max":6,"optimal":4,"rationale":"Highly parallelizable with minimal dependencies"},"security_implementation":{"min":3,"max":4,"optimal":3,"rationale":"Tight coordination essential to avoid vulnerabilities"},"performance_optimization":{"min":3,"max":5,"optimal":3,"rationale":"Optimizations must be coordinated to avoid conflicts"}},"key_principles":["Start with minimum agents and scale up only if needed","Each additional agent adds n-1 communication channels","Task modularity determines parallelization potential","Balance specialization benefits with coordination costs"],"efficiency_factors":{"resource_efficiency":"Diminishing returns typically after optimal count","coordination_overhead":"Grows quadratically with agent count","parallelization_potential":"Varies by task type and dependencies"}}

Optimal agent counts - Simple CRUD: 2-3 agents. Complex System Design: 5-7 agents. Testing & QA: 4-6 agents (parallelizable). Security: 3-4 agents (tight coordination). Performance: 3-5 agents. Key: Communication overhead grows as n(n-1)/2, start minimal and scale as needed.

JWT Token Management service implemented with TDD. Features: token generation (access + refresh), verification with blacklist check, refresh token rotation, token revocation. Uses Redis for refresh token storage and blacklist. Result pattern for error handling. All tests passing (13/13). Location: backend/src/services/auth/jwt/

Important: Added unique jti to both access and refresh tokens to ensure uniqueness. Redis SCAN used instead of KEYS for production safety. Token expiry parsing supports s/m/h/d units. Blacklist automatically expires with token. TypeScript strict mode enforced throughout.

indexOptimization: Consider periodic index rebuilding for optimal performance
